Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a New Thermal Ionization Mass Spectrometer for High-Precision Isotope Chronology and Chemistry
Award.AbstractNarration:
With assistance from this award, the Department of Geological Sciences at the University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill (UNC-CH) will acquire a new thermal ionization mass spectrometer to perform high-precision measurement of isotope ratios. The instrument will be used for high precision age determination to investigate the rates of geologic processes, and the analysis of isotopes as tracers to address questions in plate tectonics, petrology, paleoclimatology, environmental geology and archaeology. Specific research in the laboratories by the PIs includes investigation into the rates of magma accumulation associated with "supervolcanoes"; the connections between magmatism and economic gold, silver and molybdenum mineralization; ancient climates as recorded in the sediments of the US middle Atlantic coastal plain; and the carbon sequestration potential of oceanic crustal rocks. Our research is integrated with many geochronologic techniques and is playing a significant role in intercalibration of techniques.

The lab will continue a strong history of teaching graduate and undergraduate students from both UNC-CH and elsewhere. We fully support external users (PIs and students, mostly supported by NSF) by providing data, but more importantly, by training them in techniques for sample preparation, data acquisition and analysis. The lab actively participates in the NSF-funded Increasing Diversity and Enhancing Academia (IDEA) program by sponsoring and training undergraduate students drawn from underrepresented groups in the geosciences. The lab is a participant in the national EARTHTIME initiative and regularly contributes data to national and international geologic databases including NAVDAT and EarthChem.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We were awarded funding for a new Thermal Ionization Mass Spectrometer in August 2013. We selected a Phoenix62 (manufactured by IsotopX – http://www.isotopx.com/) with nine faraday detectors and a Daly ion-counting system, and two sets of amplifier cards (and two amplifier housings) fitted with one set each of 10-11 and 10-12 Ω resistors for purchase. Unfortunately, as we were about to place the order in October 2013, the Federal Government shut down and we temporarily lost access to the funding. The instrument on the floor at the factory in the UK that was intended for the University of North Carolina was sold to a different buyer, and we had to wait for another instrument to be built. The instrument was finally built and shipped at the end of April, 2014. The instrument was installed in a newly renovated laboratory with isolated temperature control and set–up began in early May. Laboratory renovation was not included in the NSF request and was fully supported by the existing Mass Spectrometry Laboratory at UNC (under the direction of PI Coleman). By mid-June (near the end of the award period) the instrument had passed preliminary tests and was cleared for running the first unknowns on the faraday detectors.

 

Since then, we have been principally running neodymium (Nd) isotopes for internal projects and collaborators at Virginia Tech, the University of Wisconsin, Oshkosh and the University of Alabama. The Nd standard (JNdi) yields 143Nd/144Nd = 0.512106 ± 0.000007 (2-σ). The samples we are running for the University of Alabama were analyzed by the students – thus the lab is continuing its tradition of training students. Most recently, we began analyses for a student from the University of California, Santa Barbara. He has been in the lab for two weeks and is learning every step of sample preparation, data collection and analysis. All samples are running extremely well and we have even been able to run Nd samples automatically – something that was unheard of in recent years on the aging Sector-54 spectrometer.

 

We have yet to fully explore the capabilities of the Daly ion-counting system. Replicate analyses of the EarthTime (http://www.earth-time.org/) 100 million year old uranium/lead (U/Pb) standard are presently scattered more than is acceptable. IsotopX is working with us to improve results (in fact, two technicians from the factory are presently in the lab). We anticipate clearing up these minor problems within the next few weeks. Ironically, this effort has been slowed somewhat by the increased demand for instrument time from internal and external users. Without two instruments running nearly around the clock, we would be much more significantly behind in our progress.

 

In addition to the mass spectrometer, we also purchased a new filament outgassing bench (DG60) from IsotopX. The new bench is capable of outgassing up to 60 filaments with minimal personnel time and a near zero failure rate. This has proven critical to keeping both instruments running and has reduced labor costs for filament preparation dramatically.

 

With the onset of data collection only a few months ago, and serious data collection beginning only a month or so ago, we have yet to generate any publications from data acquired in the new lab. Given the intense pressure from UNC students and highly productive PIs at other Universities, we are confident that these publications will be coming very quickly.
